aboutText:
Japanese Imperial House (Japanese: 皇室; kōshitsu), also known as the Imperial Family and the Yamato dynasty, or Sumera-gi, is a general term used to refer to the Japanese royal dynasty - the Emperor and members of the imperial family. According to the current Constitution of Japan, the Emperor is the "symbol of the state and of the unity of the people." Other members of the imperial family perform ceremonial and public duties but do not have any role in state affairs. The duties of the Emperor are inherited by their male children.

The Japanese monarchy is considered the oldest continuous hereditary monarchy in the world. The Imperial House recognizes 126 monarchs, starting with the legendary Emperor Jimmu (traditionally dated to February 11, 660 BC) and continuing to the current Emperor Naruhito.

Historical evidence of the first 29 emperors is based on legends, but there is solid evidence of the hereditary line since Emperor Kinmei ascended the throne 1500 years ago

family.name: Emperor Akihito
family.description: The reigning Emperor of Japan, 125th in the dynasty
family.cardInfo: His posthumous name will be Heisei. Currently, Akihito is the only reigning emperor in the world.

items.cardTitle: Studied at Gakushuin University's Peers' School (Kadzoku)
Studied politics at Gakushuin University's Faculty of Politics and Economics
Assumed a number of state duties, including participation in the opening ceremony of the parliamentary session
Became the Emperor of Japan, succeeding his father on the throne

family.name: Emperor Hirohito
family.description: Emperor of Japan, 124th in the dynasty
family.cardInfo: Commander-in-chief of the Japanese forces, held the rank of British honorary general and later, honorary field marshal.

items.cardTitle: Studied at the Peers' School (Kizoku) for children of the highest aristocracy
Studied at the Special Institute of the Crown Prince under the guidance of the best scholars of the Tokyo Imperial University and the highest military ranks of Japan
Became the Emperor of Japan
Death of Emperor Hirohito

family.name: Emperor Taishō
family.description: Emperor of Japan, 123rd in the dynasty
family.cardInfo: The period of Japanese history under the reign of Emperor Yoshihito is called the Taishō period.

items.cardTitle: Was proclaimed Crown Prince
Ascended to the throne
Due to poor health, he was forced to retire from public duties
Death of Emperor Taishō

family.name: Emperor Meiji
family.description: Emperor of Japan, 122nd in the dynasty
family.cardInfo: The period of Japanese history under the reign of Emperor Yoshihito is called the Taishō period. His posthumous name was Mutsuhito, although he is occasionally referred to as 'Emperor Mutsuhito' outside Japan, deceased emperors in Japan are only referred to by their posthumous name.

items.cardTitle: Renamed the city of Edo to Tokyo
By imperial decree, autonomous regions were abolished and the country was divided into 72 prefectures
Tokyo became the capital of the country
Death of Emperor Meiji

family.name: Emperor Komei
family.description: Emperor of Japan, 121st in the dynasty
family.cardInfo: Emperor Komei was the last emperor to receive an imperial name posthumously.

items.cardTitle: Received the title of Crown Prince
Became the Emperor of Japan
Embarked on a path of restoring cooperation with the shogunate to implement a course against foreigners
Death of Emperor Komei

family.name: Emperor Sakuramati
family.description: Emperor of Japan, 115th in the dynasty

items.cardTitle: Became the Crown Prince
Became the Emperor of Japan
Abdicated in favor of his son Tohito
Death of Emperor Sakuramati

family.name: Emperor Higashiyama
family.description: Emperor of Japan, 113th in the dynasty
family.cardInfo: Ascended to the throne after the abdication of Emperor Reigen

items.cardTitle: Birth of Emperor Higashiyama
Received the title of Crown Prince
Almost lost power after the incident with the 47 ronin
Abdicated in favor of his fifth son, Prince Yasuhito
